Award.AwardTitle: An investigation into compositionally heterogeneous plume clusters in 3D spherical geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Observations from seismology reveal two large regions of the lowermost mantle, beneath Africa and the Pacific, that exhibit slower-than-average seismic wavespeeds. Additional observations infer the cause of these anomalies to include both thermal and compositional heterogeneity. A few, competing hypotheses exist to explain them, each of which have significant consequencestoward our understanding of mantle convection patterns,
thermal transport, geochemical evolution, and cooling of the Earth?s interior. Here, we test the hypothesis that the large seismic anomalies beneath Africa and the Pacific are due to the interaction of ancient, subducted oceanic crust with plumes of hot, upwelling mantle that are expected to form in these regions. By performing 3D numerical modeling studies of mantle convection, combined with processing our results in a manner that best reproduces the distortion inherent to seismological techniques, we will examine whether this hypothesis is dynamically feasible. If so, we will investigate the important thermal and chemical transport properties associated with it, comparing and contrasting them to those of competing ideas. We will investigate how well this hypothesis fits numerous geological, geochemical, and seismological constraints, with the ultimate goal of understanding the nature of large-scale mantle convection. Combined with advances from other research, this research will work toward the larger goal of understanding how mantle convection causes plate tectonics.

The first part of this project is to perform a comprehensive fluid dynamical study to better understand the fundamental dynamics associated with multiple plumes in the presence of compositional heterogeneity. Using numerical finite-element modeling in 3D, spherical geometry, we will investigate the morphology, time-dependent dynamics, heat transport properties, and expected surface expression of mantle plume clusters in an environment
dominated by external stress forces (i.e., background convection) and various degrees of compositional heterogeneity. Secondly, we will investigate whether compositionally-heterogeneous plume clusters are consistent with observations from seismology and geology. Employing Earth?s plate history to guide subduction patterns in thermochemical numerical models, we will investigate how subducted oceanic crust is segregated into upwelling mantle regions. Through tomographic filtering of geodynamical model results, we will investigate how well plume clusters, combined with compositional heterogeneity, fit observations of seismic tomography, compared to other conceptual thermochemical mantle models. Furthermore, we will investigate the expected surface expression of plume clusters, determining their consistency with characteristic patterns of hotspot islands observed on Earth?s surface.

This grant partially funded 4 PhD graduate students in the field
of geological sciences toward their dissertation research.  Teresa Lassak defended in 2009 and is
currently working at Exxon Mobil. 
Abigail Bull defended in 2009 and is currently a post-doctoral
researcher at the University of Norway. 
Curtis Williams and and Mingming Li are currently finishing their dissertation
research here at Arizona State. This grant also funded the collaborative work
between the PI, Allen McNamara, and seismologist colleagues Ed Garnero and Sebastian Rost.  In all, the research
associated with this grant led to 5 scientific publications in peer-reviewed
journals.  The work performed primarily
used computational fluid dynamical modeling of mantle convection in
collaboration with seismology.

The overarching theme of this research centers upon
understanding the compositional structure of Earth’s mantle, particularly
whether the mantle is composed of multiple, physical reservoirs of different
materials (as hypothesized, based on seismic observations and geochemical data) or whether the mantle lacks such reservoirs (as also hypothesized, based on seismic observations).  This is important
to distinguish because the presence (or lack of) of these reservoirs would dramatically influence the nature of heat and chemical transport within Earth’s mantle.  Such an understanding forms the foundation of
recognizing the thermal and chemical evolution of the planet as well as the
driving forces causing plate tectonics at the surface.  Work supported by this grant worked toward this community-wide goal.

In Lassak et al. (2010), we investigated how seismic
observations of the topography on Earth’s core-mantle boundary could be used to distinguish between mantle models that included or lacked such compositional reservoirs.  We found that current seismic observations
were insufficient, but we were able to provide seismologists with insight
regarding the character of core-mantle boundary topography that should be investigated in future seismic studies in order to make this determination. 

Seismic tomography is used to map the temperature structure
of Earth’s mantle.  Such maps can be used
to estimate density patterns, which lead to mantle convection flow
patterns.  However, seismic observations
are incomplete and provide only a blurred view of the interior.  In Bull et al. (2010) we investigated whether the current resolution of seismic tomography is adequate to predict mantle flow patterns.  We demonstrated that it is, to
first-order.

Seismic observations reveal small patches at the base of the
mantle that are characterized by high density and dramatically reduced elastic moduli.  These are named ultra low velocity zones
(ULVZs).  In McNamara et al. (2010), we investigated whether the locations of ULVZs can be used to map the locations of
large compositional reservoirs in Earth’s lower mantle.    We
found that ULVZs are expected to be located along the margins of compositional reservoirs, which is consistent with seismic observations of ULVZs being located along the margins of large low shear-velocity provinces (LLSVPs) in the lowermost mantle (beneath the Pacific and Africa).

are compositional reservoirs.
